awd_titl_txt: Multiphase Reactivity of Atmospheric Organic Radicals: Gas- vs. Liquid- vs. Particle-phase Chemistry
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Chemistry Division's Environmental Chemical Sciences Program. Prof. Jesse Kroll and William Green and their graduate and undergraduate students study the reactions of highly reactive species in the atmosphere, called radicals, with organic compounds. Many environmental chemical processes central to human health, ecological health, and climate occur via the oxidation of organic compounds. This includes the chemical reactions that control the levels of air and water pollutants. The reaction mechanisms can be extremely complex, involving a large of number of chemical intermediates and products. Highly reactive radical intermediates, organic peroxy radicals (RO2) and alkoxy radicals (RO), are formed. These radicals can react via a number of channels, and form a wide range of products. This project aims to improve our understanding of the rates and the products of these reactions. The focus is on how the reaction conditions may control such reactivity. This understanding can ultimately lead to improved models of a wide range of important environmental processes. This enables better predictions and ultimately more informed policy decisions. 
This project involves both experimental (laboratory) and computational (modeling) studies of RO and RO2 radical reactivity under a wide range of environmental conditions.  In the experiments, the radicals are generated by photolysis of appropriate precursor molecules. This is done in the gas phase (using a flow reactor), the bulk liquid phase (using a liquid batch reactor), and within submicron aerosol particles (in an aerosol flow tube). Products are detected primarily by two instruments, an aerosol mass spectrometer for the condensed-phase products and a chemical ionization mass spectrometer for the gaseous products. The laboratory studies are carried out in parallel with the modeling work. This links rates and product distributions with detailed chemical mechanisms. Computational tools include quantum-chemical calculations of structures and energies, calculations of reaction rates, and chemical kinetic modeling of complex reaction mechanisms using the Reaction Mechanism Generator.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project involved the detailed study of the atmospheric chemistry of organic radicals, reactive species formed during the oxidation of organic compounds. Such oxidation processes are central to human health, ecological health, and climate; their mechanisms can be extremely complex, involving a large of number of chemical intermediates and products. In particular, two classes of radical intermediates, organic peroxy radicals (RO2) and alkoxy radicals (RO), are formed, and can react further via a number of channels, and form a wide range of products. This project aimed to improve our understanding of the rates and the products of these reactions, and especially of how the reaction conditions may control such reactivity.

This project involved both experimental (laboratory) and computational (modeling) studies of RO and RO2 radical reactivity under a wide range of environmental conditions.  In the experiments, the radicals are generated by photolysis of appropriate precursor molecules. This was done in the gas phase (using a flow reactor), the bulk liquid phase (using a liquid batch reactor), and within submicron aerosol particles (in an aerosol flow tube). Products were detected primarily by two instruments, an aerosol mass spectrometer for measuring the condensed-phase products and a chemical ionization mass spectrometer for measuring the gaseous products. The laboratory studies are carried out in parallel with the modeling work, to link measured rates and product distributions with detailed chemical mechanisms. Computational tools include quantum-chemical calculations of structures and energies, calculations of reaction rates, and chemical kinetic modeling of complex reaction mechanisms using the Reaction Mechanism Generator (RMG).

A range of studies of RO and RO2 radicals were carried out as part of this project. In one study, gaseous RO radicals were generated from the UV irradiation of organic nitrite (RONO) compounds, and the full range of reaction products were measured. Product formation relied critically on the levels of nitrogen oxides (NOx), pointing to the importance of RO2+NO2 reactions in controlling the overall reactivity of the system. In another, RO radicals were formed in the liquid phase (again by UV photolysis of RONO compounds), allowing for an examination of how the physical phase and chemical environment of the radicals affect the products formed. Results indicate the importance of unimolecular reactions, as well as reactions of radicals with inorganic reaction partners; however no reactions between radicals and solvent molecules were observed.

In addition, computational studies of RO2 radical chemistry enabled the prediction of RO2 behavior over a wide range of conditions, such as pressure, temperature, and NOx level (spanning atmospheric through combustion conditions). It was also shown that in aerosol particles, oxidation reactions could be driven by stochastic (rather than statistical) kinetics, due to the small numbers of radicals per particle. This could potentially lead to much faster reactions that would be expected from statistical (concentration-based) rate calculations. Finally, RMG was used to aid in the identification of new reactions of atmospheric RO and RO2 radicals. A number of recently-identified reactions were predicted using this approach, as well as some reactions that have not previously been proposed as atmospherically important; these represent important targets for future research.

 


Last Modified: 09/29/2021
Modified by: Jesse Kroll
